title: Desktop Fire Tornado
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It's the Desktop Inferno™! Now YOU can enjoy a dancing pillar of fire on your desktop. Be the envy of the office with this swirly whirly firey thingie. It's not for kids, by the way. Or irresponsible people. I have no idea what to tag this with, or in which category to place it. Well. It has electronics in it. That's a start.

Originally made as a going away gift for a colleague who left us for research into future energy sources, this thing is the joint effort of several creative heads and our unused bits and bobs from desktops and workshops. My friend, and science showman, PK, had the idea and the tiny basket, Roger the astrophysicist supplied the old 80 mm computer fan and some solid design advice, workshop wizard Fredric saved us from disaster with a small step-down power converter and I scavenged our science centre for the rest of the stuff we needed, designed the laser cut bits and put it all together. It was an ad hoc one off, and I didn't document the process, but I'll try to describe the basics. To put this together, you'll need:
-The laser cut parts
-Some glue for the laser cut parts
-Two short screws for the battery lid (It's the part inside the large circle among the laser cut parts)
-One 80 x 80 x 25 mm 12 V PC cooling fan
-A 9 V battery clip with ditto battery, or some other power supply
-A tiny adjustable step down converter to get the speed right
-A two way switch like the one in the picture, 6 mm in diameter where it goes through the box
-One metal mesh circular desktop pen holder basket thingie
-Some accelerant for the fire, we used bio ethanol
-A small cup to keep the accelerant centered in the basket. One of those aluminium cup thingies from a tea light works perfectly.
-A lighter
-Soldering equipment Putting it all together:
Check the fan first. It should run at some speed with 9 V supplied. It probably runs too fast. It should run at a leisurely speed. Enough to make the air move, but not spray your office or workshop with burning accelerant. You don't want that. Nope. That's why the step down converter is crucial. But we'll get to that later. When you know that the fan works, thread the leads from the fan through the laser cut plate with the small hole in it. You should thread it through this middle panel before you go any further. Otherwise, you're in for a de-soldering job later on (Don't ask...). Solder the circuit so that the switch can turn the power on and off (Yeah, that's how I roll) on the battery (upside) side of the step down converter, not the fan side. Otherwise, the converter will draw power even when the power to the fan is off. Solder the leads from the fan to the terminals on the downside. Check that your circuit works. Glue the aluminium cup to the centre of the basket and glue the basket in the exact centre of the fan. Let the glue set. After the glue has set, it's time to adjust the speed of the fan. There should be a tiny trim potentiometer on the step down. Turn it all the way down to the slowest speed while using a fresh battery. Put some lighter fluid/ accelerant in the aluminium cup. Light it whilst laughing manically. Now slowly turn the speed up until you're satisfied with the tornado. I believe we ended up somewhere between 4 and 5 V for a decent speed. Smile and say WOW! All the electronics go into the lower compartment of the box. Make sure you fasten the switch before you assemble the box, and check that the step down isn't interfering with the battery lid. You should be able to slide the battery in without problems. The large, square panel with the big circular hole goes over the fan with the basket sticking up through the hole, the solid square panel is the bottom of the box, as you've probably guessed. If you're happy with the fit of the parts, glue it together. There you go. Hours of fun. Just don't leave it unattended, don't use petrol/ gasoline as the accelerant and don't let kids play with it. In other words, use it at your own risk, with care.

author: Yngel

description.text:
Hello fellow inventors and tinkerers. I present to you a rolling model of the vintage Toyota FJ40. This toy car is designed to work with standard skateboard bearings, so if you have some laying around feel free to print this out.   
I'm not a huge fan of using rafts and support structures but unfortunately this will need them for the body panels and the chassis. Parts fit together tightly, so used some sandpaper and/or hobby knife to clean out the parts the fit together.  
Accesories will come at a later time.(ie. bumpers, headlight domes, lift kits, different wheels)

comments.text: I just got my printer going tonight and found this after searching for Land Cruiser then FJ40.  My local club-mates are going to be super jealous if I can get this design to work well. Thanks so much for doing the hard work on this.

remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

title: Suite Redux: Greg's Wade Extruder & Herringbone 9/47 Gears

description.text:
I wanted openSCAD source for the Greg's Wade extruder so I could tweak how well components fit. Unfortunately, the available source didn't seem very user friendly as far as understanding the design and tweaking it. I also realized that adjusting the motor mounting holes was going to require an understanding of the herringbone gear designs, and the source I found for those also seemed lacking as far as useability. Design files provided here reflect a pretty substantial overhaul of the openSCAD source scripts for both, with a focus towards people being able to tailor the designs to their liking. Want to tailor the Wade block for the nature of the cut in your hobbed bolt or to reflect the use of 1.75mm filament in a PTFE feed tube? Want to improve the fit of the bearings? Want to adjust the motor mount location, perhaps experimenting with a belt drive instead of gears? Want to eliminate recessing the heads for the motor mount screws? These and other changes should be a lot easier to do with these files. I scrubbed through all the modules and algorithms, replacing hard coded constants with labeled parameters. I've tried to apply a consistent approach to parameter labels. Parameters that users would normally have a reason to adjust are separated from those that should be left alone. Files have been extensively commented. The openSCAD MCAD polyhole method is now used where possible in order to provide improved dimensional control of small holes. The featured gallery image shows the extruder and gear components installed on a MakerFarm 8-inch i3v printer, with an e3dv6 hot end, e3d hobbed bolt, and custom (unpublished) e3dv6 cooling shroud and print cooler duct. While driven by a desire for improved designs to use on the Printbus MakerFarm 8-inch i3v printer, the enhancements should have applicability to a range of printer applications. Detailed revision and usage information is included in each openSCAD file; the following is only a summary. GREG'S ACCESSIBLE WADE EXTRUDER
The revised files leverage the Greg's Wade reloaded by jonaskuehling, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379. To allow for a thicker motor mount plate, a more robust design and lighter M3 hardware, the ability to flip out the M4 spring bolts has been eliminated. Since they tend to not print well and most users don't seem to use them, the "internal" nut traps for use on the guidler hinge bolt have also been eliminated - simply use a locknut on the exposed far side of the hinge bolt. Various new options, however, have been added. Hot end support options have been expanded to include the hexagon and e3dv6 hot ends. A u-channel mounting plate tailored to exactly match the extruder base is available. A 8mm x 20mm hinge pin for the guidler can be printed. A small spacer block is available for installation on the exposed guidler spring bolt; the block can be used as a mount for an LED that lights up the recessed hobbed bolt and filament feed area. A spacer plate can be added between the motor and the motor mount; it can be used as a tie-point for extruder wiring. Finally, a hole test plate has been added that can be printed first for the purpose of testing/refining the fitment of hardware in all the holes used in the extruder design. The base has the option for mounting holes to be used with MakerFarm's type of hot end shroud that mounts to the base. The extruder base is formed by the roundCornersCube method available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812. An option to add an open source hardware logo to the Wade block is provided through use of the oshw method available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27097. An option to label the Wade block with the design filament size is available. The gregs-wade e3dv6 1r75 univ.STL file is provided mainly to show the different component options now available. It is optimized around use of a universal e3dv6 hot end for 1.75 filament, with the filament fed into the extruder base with 4mm nominal OD PTFE tube. Rather than use the STL file directly, the user parameters in the gregs-wade openSCAD file should be reviewed and adjusted for any particular printer application. HERRINGBONE 9/47 GEARS
The revised files leverage the Parametric Herringbone Gear Set by triffid_hunter, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10707. The improvements continue to leverage the Greg Frost involute_gears method now included in the openSCAD MCAD library. The user is now isolated from the puzzling need for certain involute_gear parameters to be factored by 180/pi - that adjustment is taken care of behind the scenes as the involute_gear module is used. The open cavity side of the large gear has been swapped so the printed face is now to the outside of the extruder. This has an advantage in that the open cavity can now clear the motor mounting bolts without recessing them into the Wade motor mount, and the cavity can also clear a locknut installed on the far side of the guidler hinge bolt in lieu of trying to use hidden nuts on the hinge bolt. More importantly, swapping the open cavity allows the hub of the large gear to be extended as necessary to properly space the large gear on the bearing in the Wade block without the use of any shims or washers. The amount of chamfer applied to the gear teeth seemed excessive and has been reduced. Reflecting the occasional debate on which herringbone direction is preferred, a top level geometry option is now available to define the tooth direction. Arguments have been made that reversing the tooth pattern on the gears causes the small gear to better dig into the teeth of the large gear. The top level geometry area of the file has been revamped to allow each gear to be generated individually or as a printed pair. Note that the involute_gear results are not perfect and require repair in netfabb or similar before slicing. GEARS UPDATE May 9, 2015. I've made some adjustments to improve the nut trap on the small gear and added RevA files for the herringbone gear openSCAD and STL files. Refer to my comment dated May 9 2015 for more info.

Check the openSCAD source files for more instructional info than provided here.  
The suite components are intended to be used only with each other. Do not assume compatibility of any new component with a previously printed component or a component printed from any other source.   
Review the use and include area of each openSCAD file for information on the necessary supporting modules that must be added to your environment. Modify the paths if you install custom library functions somewhere different.  
The objective here is to put you in charge of the printed parts you can achieve vs. being stuck using someone else's design.  Review and understand the applicability of the user parameters in the openSCAD files before changing them.  It is likely easy to "break" the designs by specifying invalid or incompatible user parameters.  
Note that the herringbone gears can take a few minutes to compile, and that the gear STL outputs need to be repaired using Netfabb or a similar tool before attempting to slice them.  The small gear should be printed teeth down, with proper thermal management (print cooling fan, printing multiple parts, etc.) applied.  Consideration should be given to slicing the large gear with support provided for the nut trap.   
The Greg's Wade block has the option to include support for the extended guidler hinge. Additional support in slicing may be desired there, as well as for the bearing hole on the print bed side of the block.   
If using the LED on the spring bolt block, I first scuffed up the PLA block I printed and used Zap Goo as the adhesive, letting it cure for a day or two.  Be sure to include the proper current limiting resistor for the LED and power source you are using (I used a 1000 ohm resitor with my 12V supply).  Note that the brighter the LED is operated, the more concern there may be with heat softening the adhesive. I wired the LED to a mechanical switch that allows me to turn on the LED only when swapping filament or inspecting the hobbed bolt.  
Numbers printed next to holes on the gregs-wade hole test plate correspond to numbers in the comments for each of the user definable holes parameters in the openSCAD source file.  Comments for each hole in the test_holes method include suggestions on what to look for in testing proper hardware fitment.

comments.text: Will this design work with elastic filaments like Ninja-Flex?  Are there design parameters that you would recommend tweaking to help support the flexible filament so it does not jam?
comments.author: VenMod

comments.text: I haven't tried any of the flexible filaments, so keep that in mind.  The easier-to-tailor design provided here should, however, provide at some benefits.  First, you can size the filament feed hole below the hobbed bolt to eliminate slop that could allow the filament to start flexing in undesirable ways. Second, you can adjust the offset between the filament leaving the hobbed bolt and the filament feed hole in the base of the extruder body.  Any offset is forcing some flex into the filament.  In the Wades extruder, the length of filament unsupported after the hobbed bolt is driven by clearance provisions for the bearing in the guidler, so that is something that could be looked at.  I use the extruder with a 1.75mm universal E3Dv6 hot end, which uses a PTFE liner tube.  I extended that tube up towards the hobbed bolt maybe about 2mm above the base, with an angled cut on the end that somewhat matches the hobbed bolt.  That addresses about half the distance of unsupported filament between the hobbed bolt and the extruder base.  Similar tubes could be used for other hot ends.  EDIT: Clearance for the guidler bearing is in wade_block_holes, at the comment that reads "// Round cutout in the base to mate with the bearing in the idler plate". Personally, I think adding a filament liner tube would lead to more benefit than trying to tighten up the bearing clearance hole.
comments.author: VenMod

comments.text: Thanks for the response - time to start learning SCAD and playing with the design and seeing how I can control the filament.
comments.author: Printbus

comments.text: Hey printbus, cool stuff! What's the LED on the LED block used for?
comments.author: Gmay3

comments.text: Without the ability to completely drop the guidler out of the way, the LED lighting helps with feeding filament into the extruder feed hole and can help with inspecting or cleaning the hobbed bolt.
comments.author: Gmay3

comments.text: Was reading through the gear code. Really enjoyed the commenting and details presented. Two thumbs up on this work. Now I have a usable back up for my extruder.
comments.author: itchytweed

comments.text: After some use, I noticed the setscrew nut starting to bulge the side of the small gear.  Viewing the archived gcode file for that print, I could see how I had printed it with inadequate gap fill, and I might have also simply overtightened the setscrew. I did however upload RevA versions of the herringbone openSCAD and STL files that provide more material for retaining the nut.  This was accomplished by moving the nut slightly closer to the motor shaft hole, by tightening up the clearance on the nut trap and set screw holes, and by reducing the amount of chamfer provided on the teeth side of the small gear hub.  Changes are annotated in the openSCAD file; no changes were made to the large gear.
comments.author: Printbus

author: Printbus

description.text: I wanted to improve this joint component for a better fit on rods. This thing has an internal taper which allows you to slide the rod in straight for a certain distance, then it tapers towards the top for a tighter friction fit. There is now an opening in the top, so that if you want to fasten your rod into the sleeve, you can easily just poor a bit of epoxy into the opening. The exposure to air should make for a better epoxy cure than if there were no hole. This one mates perfectly with this other thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8130 The two combined form a fairly tight joint with very little wiggle.

1) Print as many as you need
2) Slip onto end of rod
3) Rejoice! If you want a more permanent fit, then pour a little epoxy into the top of the fitting. The default size is for a 5/16" rod, but it will likely work with a M8 rod as well. Of course the OpenScad is parameterized, so you can just change the diameter to whatever you want and print your own sizes.

description.text: A simple card box for a standard poker size deck of playing cards with the added ability to be customized with a different colored ring. I didn't fillet the corners on the ring so it would have a little bit more strength to it when trying to slide it onto the base. Once installed the corners of it can be cut or sanded away to be flush with the rest of the box. The box is designed to be snug around 54 boxless playing cards, with almost no room for the cards inside to rattle. So note should be taken on your printer's tolerances. This was printed on a Dremel Idea Builder at .2mm resolution.

comments.text: This is a fabulous box for a deck of cards!  105% for a full set of Bicycle playing cards with jokers but not the box they came in, 107% worked great for the deck of cards AND the box they came in.  The bottom part of the box needed sanding but it fits great & we love it!  :-)  Thank you!
comments.author: Missa430

comments.text:
The first one that I printed was too small to hold an entire deck (with Jokers), so I reprinted it 5% larger and a casino deck fits nicely.
I really like it. good work.
comments.author: Dodger60

comments.text: Why thank you. As it is my very first thing I've modeled, I'm glad you like it! And thank you for the input. My print holds all 54 cards quite nicely. I mean, it's a pretty tight fit (my intention) so I had to do some light filing on the inside to get rid of a layer or two that was sticking out. I printed it with a Dremel Idea Builder at .2mm resolution. I'm curious what you printed yours at so I can make any adjustments I need. And once again thank you. :)
comments.author: Dodger60

comments.text: I printed mine on an UP! MINI straight from your file.  I didn't do any filing on the final print...  I was able to barely able to fit all 54 cards into the box, but it just felt it was a bit too tight as I was afraid to put unnecessary wear on the cards.  I did do a wipe with acetone to the contact areas between the top and case (to smooth it out for easier opening).  I play a lot of Texas hold'em and get my cards from a local casino (free LOL) so they either be thicker or already have some increased thickness due to use.  Keep up the good work!

description.text:
Hand switch for an auto solder paste dispenser bought on Amazon here:
http://www.amazon.com/Dispenser-Solder-Controller-Dropper-precise/dp/B00LM9J1IK/ Fits a 30CC syringe. Modeled after the 150CC version it ships with. Designed by James DeVito

Required Materials:
1) 12mm Tactile Switch (http://adafru.it/1119)
2) 3.5mm Stereo Headphone Jack (http://adafru.it/1699)
3) Stereo 3.5mm Audio Cable (http://adafru.it/876)
4) Two 4-40 nuts & screws (~1/4in) Using as thin a wire you can find, solder the switch to the tip and ring of the 1/8" jack. Bend the leads underneath so that they fit in place, and screw the two sides together. Tighten once around the syringe.

Enclosure for the IpSonCompact PCB. IpSonCompact (http://www.koncon.nl/ipsonlab/) is an ethernet-connected sonology interface. This device can be used to hook up sensors to a computer in order to create digital musical instruments.
The enclosure enables quick and safe mounting of the PCB to any project and cools several components.

Updated: uploaded newest files for top enclosure. This file is ready to be cut and engraved in one part on an Epilog (standard FabLab laser cutter)

I needed to make the fitting of the clevis a bit tighter so the elbows would not be so wobbly. This thing is a little bit more precise, when mated with the current female version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8129 By default, the diameter of the opening is 1/4", which is perfect to fit a steel dowel pin as an axle. The depth is 3/8" by default, which is perfect to fit two of these on the ends of a steel dowel pin that is 1 1/4", leaving 1/2" gap between them. So, these two things combined form a nice elbow joint where one end is 1/4" and the other is 5/16", or whatever sizes you need.

1) Print a few of these
2) Slip onto the end of a 1/4" rod of some sort
3) Rejoice! It is a tight friction fit. You might want to add a bit of epoxy depending on your usage. You can also print it a fraction of a millimeter smaller, and use a heat gun to relax it while doing an even tigher friction fit. I find the fit to be just fine for my 1/4" steel dowel pins.

• print either .dxf or .pdf at 1:1 scale(do not scale or fit to page) to a piece of transparency paper.

description.text: This derivative has a couple of enhancements over the original to satisfy some overly restrictive constraints. For the Renosis DeltaBot, he created a servo mount which had an offset to allow the arm to swing below the plane of the platform (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7554). That's a good thing. This thing takes the design a bit further and adds both an offset, and a downward angle. This gives the arm a much broader range of motion without interfering with the edge of the platform. In addition, getting the servos into the old design was quite a task, requiring the disassembly of the servo, which is not the most friction free thing to do. So, this design has an open top, which will allow you to muscle the servo into place, without having to take it apart. Although it is still a nice tight friction fit, you'll probably want to actually use some M3 screw/nuts to fasten the servo to the mount as when it moves, it will likely wiggle around in the mount. Lastly, I still use a friction fit on the shelf. You will likely want to either epoxy the mount to your shelf, or drill a couple of holes where you can use screws or other fasteners. I must confess, this is not my best OpenScad. To get the fillet, I really hacked it up. So, if you change sizes, or the angle, you'll probably have to change that little portion. UPDATE: Made the sleeve width shorter by 2mm as it was too tight on a couple of my servos.

1) Print a few of these
2) Slip standard hobby servos into place
3) Slip the mounted servo onto a 6.5mm thick shelf (quarter inch plywood)
4) Rejoice!

title: K8200 Case / Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello world!
This is an idea for an enclosure for your 3D Printer. The advantages are the same for all printers without an enclosure. I made it using 40mm styrodur plates. These are very easy to cut. To put them together I used two-sided tape and standard screws for wood.
On the left side there are the front-door hinges, the window in the door is a glass-plate from an old picture frame. There's also an opening to access the z-axis and the adjustment. Here the advantages of an enclosure:
  • My heated bed now reaches 110°C (95°C before)
  • The noise reduced really much, the printer is next to my bed and now it's possible to sleep without earplugs.
  • The temperatur inside the enclosure is much higher than room temperature, what is a great help for printing ABS (cause the layers have less temp difference => at least less warping, in my case I don't have warping anymore)
  • It's easier to mount a fume extractor (important for ABS) cause the fume can be lead systematically, you can mount my filter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798506) on the upper stabilzer bar.
    • The print results with my K8200 are now really amazing! My changes on my printer: Z-Axis Upgrade (K8204, ~60 Euro), E3D v6 Hotend (~55 Euro), a really great new z-axis motor mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144813) and the better z-axis adjustment (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229328). Stay awesome & keep printing!

comments.text: If interested, 3DPrintClean is about to release the 3DPrintClean enclosure and filtration system. Our system enables 3D printing in PLA, ABS, HIPS, and other media, without external ventilation. See: www.3dprintclean.com for details.

Now that I'm pretty sure about the way in which I want to hold tools on my PolyBot, I need a single piece effector (tool holder). This derivative puts the axle mounts on the base plate directly. This makes for a single piece to print instead of the keyed version it derives from. The axle holes are designed to take a sleeve bearing (OD - 3/8", ID - 1/4", length - 1/2"). It is a very tight fit, and you might need to use a vise to get the sleeve bearings into the axle mounts. Once you do though, you have a nice axle where you can attach a male clevis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8130 If you use a 1 1/4" steel dowel pin as the axle, you will have a nice, minimal wiggle, axle/joint combination. Although the axle mounts are angled outward, it is still a tight fit for a tool to be mounted. A future design might change this arrangement. In the meantime, you can simply print the tool larger to get more separation. This is challenging to print as there's a lot of surface area, and it will tend to want to warp. So, print with a high raft to absorb some of that warpage.

1) Print one of these
2) Press fit sleeve bearings into the axle mounts
3) Put 1/4" steel dowel pins into the sleeves as axles
4) Attach male clevis, or other rod ends to axles
5) Rejoice!

comments.text: Were you having issues with the previous design with the keyed attachments or did you just feel like they served no purpose? I liked the key design because I could print multiple effectors to attach diffferent tools to and be able to quickly swap them out. The problem with this though, is that the keyed joints might wear after a while and not hold as well.
comments.author: Renosis

comments.text: Just a convenience thing.  Either end effector can work just fine.  I do want to create a standardized size of the hole and mounting hole placements, but as you point out, you can just put a whole new effector in place.
comments.author: Renosis

comments.text: Ah that's a smart way of doing things. Because you weren't sure what would be needed of the effector, you made it completely modularized. Now that you know exactly what you need, you made a more permanent part.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yep, like that.

Fully 3D printable frames and temples (sides). Will need screws and lenses from a donor pair of sunglasses. Check out my tutorial video to learn how to make it yourself! http://youtu.be/D3MMoaojVuM

comments.text: Hi, I watched your youtube video of you making glasses frames, and you made it look very easy. However, I recently paid a company to produce some frames for me, and when I received them, they did not resemble a typical pair of glasses. I'm very new to the 3D printing world and for some reason I thought this would be a simple task. I been attempting to reach out to other people/companies but it seems like they work on projects of a larger scale, and not glasses frames. So I was very glad to come across your video. Also with my frames I have added a new feature that I want to introduce to the eyewear industry. I would like to share more of my project with you and receive some good advice. Please contact me at [email protected] Thanks (even if your not interested, still contact me to let me know)

title: Xbox 360 PSU Socket Housing for printrbot GO

description.text:
The original Xbox 360 power supply is a very good match for the printrbot GO if you want to use a heated bed.  The PSU supplies 203 watts at around 12 V and is also relatively portable (it's like a chunky laptop PSU).  
Although you could splice the output wires into a common ATX connector, you could also keep the original plug and lift a connector off of a discarded Xbox motherboard (there are plenty of these on eBay) and wire that to the printrboard instead, giving you an easy and elegant way to unplug it.  
This housing for the PSU connector creates a nice permanent mount for the connector in the side of the GO.  Just cut a 25 mm x 27 mm (approx.) hole in the side panel of the GO and mount it using two of the existing panel screws and add two more for the top of the housing.

The SCAD file does have some parameters, but was not really designed to be tweaked, that's just how I put it together.  Consequently, tweaking any parameters will doubtless require additional manual tweaking of other hard-coded dimensions to make everything fit right..

description.text:
DESIGNED WITH CHEAP 3D PRINTERS IN MIND  
Moving poseable model that is snap fit so no glue or sanding required per se, if you have a cheap 3d printer you may need to sand the joints to get them to fit properly. If in some models you find yourself asking: "Why did he even disconnect that from the part?" Its so it would be easier on cheap printers and so that failed print jobs were more forgiving in the amount of plastic used or broken joints could be easily replaced without a whole new reprint. Stands about a foot tall  
I haven't tested this as I wont be near a 3D printer for while but I have had experience printing poseable models so I am confident that it will work as intended.   
If you think that any improvements can be made please do not hesitate to leave it in the comments and I will update the model.  
When I was 16 I wrote a book that had a long range artillery mech that used dimensional technology to warp its ammunition directly into its barrel. This is a direct recreation of that mech. Heavily inspired by the BattleTech franchise, it is included in the tags
This is still a work in progress - updates coming soon.

additional materials:
-hot glue gun 1 - print. I printed these with my default settings: 0.1mm layer height and .8mm shell thickness, no support or raft. I used PLA for the prints shown here.
2 - carefully remove from build plate. work inward around perimeter.
3 - put a dot of hotglue on each corner, fold up and hold.
4 - continue until you have two hemispheres glued up.
5 - put glue around seam and close up. note: to get just the protrusions a different color, I switched filament at exactly 2.05mm with the use of a software plugin

title: Prusa i3 Rework ATX PSU Mount

description.text: This allows you to attach an ATX PSU to the side of the Rework frame. This works only with about 90 mm of the rear 8mm rod sticking out from the frame. You'll need two 1/4" screws and nuts to mount the one leg to the frame. Then there are four screws to assemble the parts. The file ATX PSU Holder is a combined part, I broke it up because I was having problems with it printing in ABS without delamination.

comments.text: Thanks for the comment. I'm using a 600 Watt PC PSU. Basically it is just running off the 12 Volt rails (usually the ones that were the 4 pin plugs. This one had two of those plugs, so two of the positive and negative wires are connected together and then put into the main RAMPS 1.4 plug and then the other set are connected to the Heatbed plug. I basically just cut all the other wires off inside the power supply. Then put an insulator over the wire ends that I cut off. I don't suggest you do this if you are not comfortable and careful about working inside the PSU.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17970
This is about as simple a thing as I can imagine. But it serves a purpose for those with a 7 x 12 lathe so here it is.
I have seen several examples of this solution for determining drilling depth with a lathe. In each case the operator used aluminum or acrylic or some other material which required machining. I was thinking along the same lines, digging through scrap stock when it dawned on me I could print it.
I guess the point is when you are modifying a lathe you think to machine a part. When you need a jig for a table saw you think to cut it from plywood or MDF.
Being able to print something opens up a whole new way of thinking about how to solution things.
Print it. Mount it to your tail stock. Try to buy the dial indicator when it is on sale.

comments.text: I'm just learning to use a lathe recently, on a Grizzly 7x12.  The last thing I did was drill out the center of some pulleys on it.

I wanted to have a landing gear that could keep my battery from scratching the floor everytime I landed, and keep the props away from the grass as well !!  
Those are super light, and pretty sturdy so far, I'm landing very easy each time...

You'll need 4 x M3 nuts (Lock nuts prefered) and 4 m3 x20 socket head cap screws:

title: Auger paddles for a Scotts Turf Builder Pro EdgeGuard seed spreader

description.text:
My friend's dad kept losign the original hopper paddles for his walk-behind spreaders. These fit snugly on the hext shaft and also drop down 1/4" into the hole in the hopper to minimize the slop in the shaft. These were printed in PLA and the hex hole size is 0.44" whereas the shaft size is 0.43". The shrinkage in the PLA makes these fit perfectly. They've been tested with four bags of seed so far and work great!  
These were designed for the Scotts Turf Builder Pro Edge Guard spreader but should work with any other walk-behind spreader with a 0.43" hex shaft and 2" diameter paddle.

comments.text: Thanks for making this.   My paddle broke and I was going to design one.  I thought is was a long shot  that anyone would have made one, but here it is.  Works great.  Thanks!

quick openscad code to make some small clips.  Fully parametric for easy adaptation to a specific clipping need.

Part one of two of a wedding present.
Inspired by Japanese Cherry Blossom Paintings

Printing Instructions
1) PLA at 205˚C Heated Bed at 50˚C
2) Layer height of 0.1mm
3) Printed reeeeeeeeeaaally slowly (Max speed 70mm/s with outlines ~20mm/s)
4) Printed at a extrusion width of 0.3mm
5) 4 shells (outline and top/bottom)
6) Switch filament color at 0.4mm height ~This was the hardest print I've ever attempted~
Time: ~11 hours .STL
Basic print file - two parts
Part 1: The base part of the painting frame and tree outline
Part 2: Cherry Blossoms (will overlap with Part 1 model) .factory
Simplify3D file that has all the print settings and model pre-setup. The Settings should match the "Printing Instruction" .mix
MeshMixer file of .STLs Part 1 and 2 for your editing pleasure .SLDPRT
Original Solidwork file used to create Part 1 .STL file for your editing pleasure .gcode & .3xg
The print-ready files used to print the model. Should match the "Printing Instructions" settings for PLA. Requires Sailfish firmware.

OK, Any makers out there that can help me.  I am adding pneumatic tubes inside this part (The magenta in the wireframe), and when printing they are filling in what I suspect to be support material.  I am using Simplify 3D which is awesome for scaling and such, just cannot figure out how to keep those tubes hollow.  
Made these guys to replace some PVC items that are on our machine that kept breaking. So far so good.   Note: The originals work well, but I am embellishing with a pneumatic lifting system, hence the notes above.  
Next plan is to put pneumatic tunnels and lead the to the pick up tips to pulse a lifting jet to break the printed sheets off of the table for easier removal.

So very meta. A tiny 3D printer you can print. Like reprap, but smaller.

You may need supports to print, depending on the orientation you print the parts.
  • Print printsurface.stl in natural PLA
  • Print cart.stl in white
  • Print the other parts in whatever color you'd like the Cube to be
  • Glue cart and gantry to base (do cart first, it will give you a better glue surface to use for gantry).
  • Glue zaxis.stl to the gantry
  • glue the print surface to the zaxis.
  • If you have a tiny part somewhere, you can glue that to the print surface to simulate a little complete print (see my photos).
  • (optional) glue a little but of cable between the hole in the gantry and the head to simulate the filament.

author: danithebest91

title: Sunhokey Improved Glass bed clamp and X-carriage Stability

description.text:
I have read from our Sunhokey group the problem on X-carriage having too much play. I say you are not alone on this... LOL After a week of printing after finishing the printer assembly I noticed the same issue on my printer. The X-carriage plays a lot and even exaggerated by the backlash. Yes the cause is the small linear block/bearing installed on the X-carriage. So I immediately ordered from the supplier a longer linear block (same as the one installed on the z-axis) as I thought it will reduce (if not eliminate) the vibration on the X-carriage thus improving stability. The longer linear block arrived after 2 weeks or so and I replaced the small linear block on the X-carriage. I just drilled additional 8 holes on the acrylic carriage to accommodate the longer linear block. And just what I thought, it works. The play/vibration was eliminated, X-carriage is now very stable, and printout improves a lot. Additional improvement was my clamping method for the borosilicate glass. According to supplier, the print size capability of this printer is 200 x 200 x 180. But due to the size of the borosilicate glass, this is not achievable. The maximum print size I can achieve (with the clip also limiting the travel area of the nozzle) is 180 x 180 x 180. Now the clip to clamp the glass is too big for me. So I thought if I can just use a very small clamping device then I can even add more space/area for the nozzle to travel thus increasing my print size capability. So I took a terminal lug and cut the crimp side and insert it to the heat bed screw (like a washer) and by using the existing leveling spring on the bed, it provided enough force to clamp the glass on the heat bed. (See photos for details) It turns out pretty good. Not only did it increased the print size (now 195 x 190 x 180) but I can also clamp and un-clamp the glass with ease. Hope this helps. Keep printing everyone... cheers! P.S.
The obj file is just a dummy file to enable this post to be published.

comments.text: I have a geeetech unit but the bed and glass issue is pretty much identical I think, my solution so far is that I have made a tiny metal C shaped bent piece of metal for the back to slide under the x axis carriage (its really low on the back) and cut one of them very short so it just goes on enough to hold it down, and it works pretty well, the metal I used is some metal strip from a local factory to bind up bundles of large steel pipes but I think you could use those metal flat strips from pallet hold downs and bundles of 2x4 wood studs (not sure what european version is of that) for transport on trucks and trains, and they just toss that stuff away usually, very good useful material, I have even made hose clamps by ringing it then bending the ends 90 degrees and punching a hole in the ends so I can run a screw through both ends to tighten it up :)

Wouldn't you prefer to spend hours and hours printing your own tablecloth clips instead of buying them for 10¢ each? LOL  
I designed and made these after reading reviews of the commercially available clips and didn't like how they were always downrated due to unexpected breakage or overnight cracking or didn't fit their table thickness.  
So voila.  
First, these are stackable. If you need to carry four or eight or a whole bunch to a picnic, they're lightweight and compact.  
Second, they're flexible. I printed mine in polycarbonate. The smallest can fit thicknesses of 3/8" to 2 1/2". The largest can fit 3/4" to 3". So for a common wood picnic table of 1 1/2" thickness, using all four is okay. The different size is unnoticeable.  
Lastly, the corners are thickened for increase stiffness, i.e., better performance.

Print one or print all four, but best to print in a material that's stiff and flexible. Note that neither ABS nor polycarbonate is UV resistant, meaning they'll degrade and get brittle after long exposure to the sun.

An assignment required for DPT100.

This is a very specialized part that hopefully will help someone else as well.
I came across this japanese pinball / gambling machine on craigslist one day a few years ago. After building a stand for it and fixing up the electronics, I struggled for years to find a perfect hopper for the steel balls that the machine uses as game tokens. I tried all sorts of plastic containers, but they were either unstable or the balls bounced right out and onto the floor. So having access to a 3d printer, I believed I could design and print the perfect solution! Above is the result. The design was modified with a dremel in the pictures as i made a few mis calculations when making adjustments to the width so it was printable. I have updated the STL file with the dremel changes so it should be good to go if you have a similar pachinko machine. I'd imagine its completely useless for any other purpose, and takes aprox 12 hours to print on the ditto +. But hey, 3d printing is all about sharing so i figured, why not! the machine was meant to be mounted in a wall, so I would assume anyone who purchased one of these machines would have the same problem I had with the balls falling all over the floor.

One side has a sort of "ball pourer" that probably does not work. This is because I had to adjust the design and make it smaller to print and did not remove this. I believe if the circles were removed, it would still fit, but i left them in because it DOES fit with them in!

comments.text: Nice work! I also have a pachinko machine. They are lots of fun. Mine had a broken cabinet, so I built a new cabinet around it, and included a catch bin and hopper in the design. Unfortunately, the hopper I made isn't very good at emptying. I plan on printing some inserts to help that out.

I printed this on a Printrbot Metal Simple, and the bridging worked well and they came apart easily. If they are fused, use Customizer to increase the tolerance.

My beloved headphones first developed a crack in their left swivel about a year ago.  The crazy glue held up for some time, but ultimately they blew apart when I was out for a run (yes, I ran with these giant headphones on).  As I looked frantically for shards of headphone in the bushes, i thought "Wait a minute, I can just print a new one!"  
This particular part ended up being much more complicated than I'd anticipated.  It holds everything together on the left side and the build logic that Denon designed is impressive (and frustrating).  It also includes features that limit rotation in two axes.  I recommend partially disassembling the other side for reference.

Printed using PLA, 100 micron layer height using a 0.4mm nozzel, Robo3D R1. I left the articulation ring open so it can be assembled without taking apart the lower arm that connects to the Left driver. I recommend partially dissassembling the other side to get a feel how this thing goes together.
To remove the existing, mangled part: Materials: Needle-nose pliers, soldering iron, tweezers, can-do attitude. Disassembly:
1) Unscrew the rectangular clamshell enclosure parts, as well as the part in question. 2) You'll have to de-solder the wires that goes to the right driver. 3) Remove the C-clip that holds the brass tube and washer in place. 4) Slide the wires out through the tube 5) slide the tube through the damaged part. Note: depending on the level of failure of your part, you may have to remove the retention spring first. 6) install part, do everything in reverse order for re-assembly. Make sure the retention spring is in correctly! see other side of headphones for reverence. I'd be really surprised and thrilled if this part ever gets used by anyone. Please post pics if you do.

Revision C updates the frame for the 8-Gear clock.
Current repository for the latest version of the clockwork library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8155 The original 8-Gear Clock Thing was getting a little crowded, and most of the gears changed in revision B, while most the other parts changed in revision C... so I figured it was time to start a new page. (EDIT: Added an ugly, beefy alternative frame that reaches around the clock so the back and front have some solidarity. Thinking about how to encase the whole clock in a big solid cube, for some real rigidity) /* The Printable Clock Project by Syvwlch,
with help from MakerBlock, rustedrobot, barrychuck,
and many others at Thingiverse. 8-Gear Clock Revision C
  • Extended frame to include escapement
  • Retro-fitted code clean-up from other clock designs
    • Revision B
  • Changed gear ratios to make a 12-hour clock, rather than a 60-hour clock
    • Revision A
  • Original release
    • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8136 CC-A-SA licensed.*/ This script uses the MCAD involute_gear library and my own clockwork library.

Print one of each STL file, or fiddle with the script, check your work with assembled(), and then generate a new STL for each part with laidOutToPrint(), and print those.
The current configuration requires five shafts to slip the sleeved gears over, outer diameter 2mm with a clearance of half a millimeter either side, so M3 may require drilling out the holes, depending on the print tolerances.
For extra solidity, use the alternate frame STLs provided.

comments.text: I started in the middle, grabbing the supports that are the least attached to other supports, using needle nose pliers. Do not twist or pull, just bend side to side. author: MakerSpatz

description.text: I've seen so many impressive spool related posts recently, so I figured I would share my creation.  I'm sure I'm not the first to take scrap parts and make something useful out of them.

In this case, I have substantial pieces of threaded rod left over every time I build a new machine.  Some pieces are long enough to be put into another machine, but some are just too short.
Since I get my bearings from old roller blades, there are always some throwaways there, but I clean them as best as I can, and use them here.

author: josemiii

description.text:
This a new encasement for a vibrator. It has a organic form. There are two different version, one of them is more thin on the top. Both version comes with a cap which are fixed with 3 M3 screws. body interaction develops OSHW development boards for vibrators.
http://www.bodyinteraction.com
Improve and make your own with Tinkercad:
https://tinkercad.com/things/5aSU5KCTWal
https://tinkercad.com/things/k8JcnN2Eqtj (wide) This video show the assembling of the 3d printed form and the Arduino compatible board:
https://youtu.be/BoJWXSxart0
http://wp.me/p2TZiU-zjS

This is a base for an Arduino Uno R3. It holds the board flush with the top, and it uses the 4 mouting holes to hold the board in place. It is also the same height as a standard breadboard and is notched on both sides so it can be attached to a breadboard.   
I have also included the sketchp file in case you want to change anythng

comments.text: Just what I've been looking for! how well do the nubs hold the board in place? could I hold it buy the base upside down without the arduino falling out?

comments.text: That's really going to depend on how well your printer makes pillars. mine always goes a little wide so they are pretty snug. I can easily hold mine upside down with no problems. worst thing to ever happen was that one of the four snapped off when i tried to pop it out. but the other three still hold it in place pretty well.
